ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I was able to ameliorate my spoken and grammatical French skills while learning about a Francophone culture in every corner of the world. This was the first French course where I felt as though I was truly able to apply my lexicon of the language, rather than being confined to grammar and vocabulary exercises.

I developed my skills in written and oral French and learned a lot about Francophone cultures and history. I especially appreciated reading narratives from many different countries and taking an honest look at the impacts of French colonialism.
I learned niche french grammar stuff and had experience talking and reading
Oral, writing, listening and reading French skills.

So many! I learned how to verbalize my thoughts with much more fluency and much less hesitation in French, I learned several useful and relevant key vocabulary words that are now incorporated into my expression in French and I acquired a lot of knowledge about French and Francophone studies.
I learned more French.
I developed a greater understanding of French grammar, vocabulary, francophone culture, and France during World War II.

Read advanced French literature, reviewed past tense, learned to recognize literary tenses, hypothetical phrases, indirect speech, relative pronouns, causative speech using "faire", imperative, subjunctive, and prepositions
Definitely improved significantly in my grammar capabilities and learned a lot about the WW2 era of France.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The breadth of literature used in this course is phenomenal. Our studies went from Senegal to Algeria to the Caribbean to Indochina to wartime France, and our knowledge of the language was enough such that we could truly have discussions and debates regarding all of the content we learned. There's a reason that my FREN 130 professor, current French professor, and students alike agree that FREN 140 is the best course in the French department's L1-L5 track.

strengths: quick grading, small class size meant we all got time to talk
weaknesses: it was sometimes difficult for Madame Burton to understand what we were trying to convey
A course that has been taught many times, great materials. Requires a high level of engagement all semester long, which can be an advantage or disadvantage, depending on the student.

Some of the strengths of this course were the many opportunities that we had to practice our oral expression and to talk about different topics of interest to us (actualits, expos...). The only suggestion I would have for an improvement would be a very minor one - I think it would be helpful to have weighted grades to the assignments on Canvas so that we could have a better idea of what grade we would probably get as the term progressed.

This class is was definitely what is was advertised as: an advanced and intensive French class. While that was effective in some respects, it was also overwhelming at times. For a lot of the class I kind of felt like I was almost teaching myself. You haver to learn the grammar through the course packet and it isn't always clearly elaborated upon in class. I did appreciate the wide range of materials we were exposed to and felt that I came away with a strong understanding of francophone culture globally, not just in France itself.
There is a lot of busy work for this course that does not increase knowledge or understanding, but the makes the course on the whole much less engaging.

Strengths: Professor Burton was phenomenal. She created a great classroom environment in which students felt completely comfortable to work on their oral proficiency. The breakout rooms were great because they fostered a familiarity with classmates. There was ample opportunity to improve speaking-wise. Weaknesses: there were no significant weaknesses, although sometimes the reading homework could be a bit too much for one night.

Strengths: done well over zoom given necessity of speech and writing during course, lots of opportunities to engage both voluntarily and on command, good balance of reading/writing/speaking practice; Weaknesses: grammar book required for course did not receive hardly any class-time attention despite its high cost so I would recommend making this book optional or incorporating its exercises into the curriculum more, relative pronouns were required during some parts of the course but not others making exams confusing for when they were/weren't needed

Strengths were the focus on grammar and speaking but I wish there could have been more low pressure writing assignments other than the major writing assignments which were worth a sizable amount of the grade for the class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: the course was still engaging virtually through breakout rooms and direct student engagement

The use of breakout rooms was very useful to practice spoken skills. Sharing materials through a single folder canvas, through screenshares and through the chat was confusing and hard to follow. It'd be great to have materials organized in a single place in the future.
I think everything worked well.
The combination of full-class and small breakout room discussion helped a lot with engagement.
Class was organized in the best way possible for the pandemic.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would without question recommend this course to another student. The breadth of literature used in this course is phenomenal. Our studies went from Senegal to Algeria to the Caribbean to Indochina to wartime France, and our knowledge of the language was enough such that we could truly have discussions and debates regarding all of the content we learned. There's a reason that my FREN 130 professor, current French professor, and students alike agree that FREN 140 is the best course in the French department's L1-L5 track.
I would recommend this course to any other student because it really grew my love for French and I feel that I improved a lot, but it did not feel too grammar heavy.

I would not recommend this course unless you really liked French. I definitely was just taking this to finish my language requirement, but the extremely high workload made it difficult to enjoy the class.
Absolutely, I would just make sure they are aware of the level of engagement and time commitment required.
Most definitely!! This course will improve their written and spoken French immensely and is such a pleasure to take.
I would recommend this class if you are willing to make the commitment. It can be a lot at times but ultimately pays off if you put in the work.
If you need to take this class for your language requirement, you should. If not, don't.
I would definitely recommend this course to any student seeking to improve their French skills and knowledge of francophone culture.

Absolutely - if you plan on continuing with French into advanced levels, this course is excellent at not only pushing your skills but also getting you into the habit of taking in French on your feet. I've taken French classes for more than 7 years, and this is the first course where I actually started to think in French and process the language in real time. I truly wasn't sure if I would ever become fluent before now, but this class really made me believe that fluency is an achievable goal.

Would recommend the class to anyone looking to improve their French grammar specifically. The class is very grammar focused, so be prepared to do a lot of work every night in order to keep up with the grammar and reading responsibilities.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: none
N/A
